sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: Microsporidia are obligate intracellular, unicellular, spore-forming eukaryotes that were initially appreciated as pathogens with the identification by Nageli in 1857 ofNosema bombycis as the etiologic agent of pébrine in silkworms (1). Since that time, approximately 220 genera and 1,700 species of microsporidia have been identified. Microsporidia are found in invertebrates and vertebrates, infecting every major animal group (2–8). While initially thought to be “primitive protozoa,” they are now understood to be closely related to fungi (8). The class or order Microsporidia was originally elevated to the phylum Microspora by Sprague in 1977 (9); however, in 1998, Sprague and Becnel indicated that Microsporidia should instead be utilized as the phylum name (10). In human infections, the following microsporidian genera have been described as etiologic agents (8) (Table 1): Nosema (Nosema corneum, reclassified as Vittaforma corneae [11]; Nosema algerae, reclassified initially as Brachiola algerae [12] and then Anncaliia algerae [13]); Enterocytozoon (14); Septata (15) (reclassified as Encephalitozoon [16]); Encephalitozoon (17–21); Pleistophora (22–24); Trachipleistophora (25, 26); Brachiola (reclassified as Anncaliia)(12); Anncaliia (13); Tubulinosema (27, 28); Endoreticulatus (29); and Microsporidium (30) (a collective group used to indicate an unclassified organism). While the majority of cases of human microsporidiosis involve the gastrointestinal tract, microsporidiosis can involve almost any human organ system (2, 8).

Microsporidia develop completely intracellularly, and there are no metabolically active stages found outside of their host cells. Development may occur in direct contact with host cell cytoplasm (Nosema, Anncaliia, and Enterocytozoon), in isolation within a vacuole formed by host cell membranes (Vittaforma and Encephalitozoon), or in a cyst-like sporophorous vesicle of pathogen origin (Pleistophora and Trachipleistophora) (Table 2). Microsporidia produce distinctive, environmentally resistant spores, and the shape and size of these spores vary depending on the species (8). In general, the microsporidia described as etiologic in human infections have ovoid, 1- to 4-μm spores (31). An important and characteristic feature of all microsporidia is the presence of an extrusion apparatus consisting of a polar tube that forms 4 to approximately 30 coils around the sporoplasm in the spore and that is attached to the anterior end of the spore by the anchoring disk (Fig. 1). The polar tube may be of uniform diameter (isofilar) or show a sharp decrease in diameter in the most posterior coils (anisofilar). When exposed to specific environmental conditions, such as passage though the host’s gastrointestinal tract, spore germination occurs and the polar tube rapidly everts, forming a hollow tube that acts as a conduit to deliver the sporoplasm to the host cell. The mechanism by which the polar tube interacts with the host cell membrane during invasion is not well understood and is a focus of active scientific investigation. If a spore is phagocytosed by a host cell, germination can also occur, enabling the polar tube to pierce the phagocytic vacuole, resulting in the sporoplasm being delivered into the host cell cytoplasm or into an adjacent host cell.

The majority of species of microsporidia have simple single-host life cycles; however, a few species have complex life cycles with multiple hosts and can form morphologically distinct spores in different hosts (e.g.,Amblyospora sp. in mosquitoes) (32, 33). The life cycle of microsporidia can be divided into three stages (Fig. 2): the infective or environmental stage (i.e., spores, which are the only stage that can survive outside of the host cell); the proliferative stage (merogonic sequence); and the sporogonic or spore-forming stage. During development, various microsporidian genera demonstrate different relationships with their host cell (34, 35) (Table 2), which probably reflects physiological and nutritional differences among the various microsporidian genera (36–38).

When spores are exposed to appropriate environmental conditions, germination occurs, and the sporoplasm is transported into the host cell via the hollow polar tube (39, 40). As soon as the sporoplasm enters the host cell, it initiates a reproduction cycle which terminates with the production of mature spores. Merogony follows, during which the injected sporoplasm develops into meronts (the proliferative stage), which multiply, depending on the species, by binary fission or multiple fission. While most microsporidia develop within the host cell cytoplasm, some genera of microsporidia will infect the nucleoplasm of the host cell or develop in both the cytoplasm and nucleus (41–44). The merogony stage is responsible for a massive increase in the number of infecting organisms (45). During merogony, many microsporidia have a simple plasma membrane, but a surface coat is present in Anncaliia, Pleistophora, and Trachipleistophora. Division can be by binary or multiple fission into two or more individuals. At the end of merogony, an electron-dense material is formed on the external face of the merozoite plasma membrane, which indicates the switch from merogony to sporogony (this step is delayed in Enterocytozoon) (46). Sporonts give rise to sporoblasts via binary or multiple fission (depending on the species); the sporoblasts go on to form mature spores without additional multiplication. In most species, the dense material on the plasma membrane in sporogony becomes the primordium of the exospore layer of the spore wall (47). The polar tube and Golgi also develop in the sporoplasm of the sporoblast (48–50). The sporoblast plasma membrane is covered by a continuous layer of dense material, which can form tubular or fibrillar expansions that protrude from the surface of the sporoblast into the parasitophorous vacuole (47). Once a host cell becomes distended with mature spores, the cell ruptures, releasing mature spores into the environment and completing the life cycle. The combination of merogony and sporogony results in a large number of spores being produced from a single infection and underlies the huge reproductive potential of these organisms.

Microsporidia have many typical eukaryote features such as a membrane-bound nucleus, an intracytoplasmic membrane system, and chromosome separation on mitotic spindles. However, unlike typical eukaryotes, they lack recognizable mitochondria, having instead a remnant organelle termed a mitosome (51); they also lack peroxisomes and have a simple vesicular Golgi complex. In addition, they have highly reduced prokaryotic-size ribosomes (52) which lack a 5.8S ribosome subunit, although sequence homologous to the 5.8S region is observed in the 23S subunit (53). Depending on the species, the genome size varies from ~2.2 Mbp (e.g., Encephalitozoon spp.) to 51 Mbp (e.g., Edhazardia aedis), and these genomes code for 2,000 to 5,000 proteins (8, 54). Genome data for the microsporidia are available online at MicrosporidiaDB.org (http://microsporidiadb.org/micro/). Compared with those of other eukaryotes, the genomes of microsporidia are reduced in size and complexity; e.g., the Encephalitozoon cuniculi genome is 2.24 Mbp. In this compact genome, gene density is high, there are almost no introns, and encoded proteins are significantly shorter than orthologous proteins in other eukaryotes (55). It is likely that this reflects an early bottleneck in the evolution of the microsporidia, with a massive gene loss resulting in a core set of conserved genes. This core set has been complemented by the expansion of transporters that facilitate the obligate intracellular life cycle of these pathogens (56). Expansion from this core set of genes has been driven by the acquisition of noncoding DNA (such as transposable elements, etc.); e.g., only 9% of the 51-Mbp Edhazardia aedis genome codes for proteins, whereas 90% of the 2.24-Mbp Encephalitozoon cuniculi genome codes for proteins (57, 58).

table.title: TABLE 2 Developmental relationships of microsporidia with their host cella

row.entry: Direct contact of microsporidian plasmalemma with the host cell cytoplasm. This is seen inEnterocytozoon bieneusi, Anncaliia, and Nosema.

entry.para: Indirect contact due to host-produced isolation

Subtype A. Microsporidia are in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV), i.e., a host-formed single membrane that surrounds the developing organism. The PV is seen in the proliferative and sporogonic phases of development, but the relationship of the developing microsporidia changes during development. Early in development, the organism has a close association with the PV membrane until the development of a thickened sporont plasmalemma, at which time they appear loose within the PV. This type of development is seen inEncephalitozoon hellem and Encephalitozoon cuniculi.

Subtype B. Throughout development, the microsporidia are surrounded by the host endoplasmic reticulum (ER), which appears as a double membrane surrounding the developing microsporidian cells. In the proliferative phase, these host ER double membranes closely follow the dividing microsporidian plasmalemma and no vacuole is seen. During sporogony, a double membraned PV, formed by the host ER, surrounds the cluster of organisms formed in sporogony. This type of development is seen inEndoreticulatus and Vittaforma.
Indirect contact due to parasite-produced isolation

Subtype A. During development, microsporidia secrete an envelope that surrounds the developing organisms. In sporogony this envelope becomes a sporophorous vesicle (SPOV) as the microsporidian plasmalemma thickens and pulls away from the secreted envelope. This type of development is seen inPleistophora.

Subtype B. During early development, the microsporidia are in direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm. As development proceeds, a membrane formed by the microsporidia isolates sporonts from contact with the host cell cytoplasm. This type of development is seen inVairimorpha.
Indirect contact due to host- and parasite-produced isolation

Subtype A. During merogony, the host ER closely associates with the microsporidian plasmalemma. As development proceeds, the developing microsporidia forms an interfacial envelope by producing “blisters” that arise from the plasmalemma, resulting in an SPOV, which can contain tubules, being formed in sporogony. This type of development is seen inGlugea and Loma.

Subtype B. During development, both the host and parasite contribute to the formation of a thick interfacial envelope surrounding the developing organisms. This type of development is seen inTrachipleistophora.

Subtype C. During development, a PV formed by the host surrounds the organisms. Within the PV, microsporidian-secreted material surrounds each organism. This type of development is seen inEncephalitozoon intestinalis.

It had been postulated, based on phylogenic analysis of their rRNA genes (59), that microsporidia were “ancient” protists (i.e., Archezoa) that diverged before the mitochondrial endosymbiosis. However, it is now appreciated, based on genome data, that microsporidia at one point in their evolution did possess mitochondria and that they still have a relic mitochondrial organelle, the mitosome, as well as possessing mitochondrial genes in their genomes (51, 60). Genome-wide sequence and synteny analyses indicate that microsporidia belong to the kingdom Fungi as either a basal branch or a sister group (61, 62). In addition, structural features seen in microsporidia, such as the presence of chitin in the spore wall, diplokaryotic nuclei, and electron-dense spindle plaques associated with their nuclear envelope, are consistent with a possible relationship between fungi and microsporidia. Recent molecular genome analysis indicates that microsporidia are derived from an endoparasitic chytrid ancestor on the earliest diverging branch of the fungal phylogenetic tree (63, 64). Phylogenetic studies suggest that the microsporidia should be placed with the Cryptomycota (65, 66) as a basal branch of the fungal kingdom (67). The Cryptomycota have been identified by environmental microbiome studies, and while poorly described at the biological level, they are closely related to the microsporidia (65). Cryptomycota that grow as intranuclear parasites of amebae have been discovered, and these parasites bear strong morphological similarities to microsporidia (9, 68). These and other microsporidia-like organisms, such as Nucleophaga terricola, Mitosporidium daphniae, and Paramicrosporidium, demonstrate that additional environmental sampling is required to completely ascertain the relationship of fungi and microsporidia, and to provide a better understanding of the Cryptomycota and the origin of microsporidia.

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Diagram of a microsporidian spore. (A) Microsporidian spores vary in size from 1 to 10 μm, with those infecting humans being from 1 to 4 μm. The spore coat is thinner at the anterior end of the spore and consists of an electron-lucent endospore (En), an electron-dense exospore (Ex), and the plasma membrane (Pm). The sporoplasm (Sp) contains ribosomes, the posterior vacuole (PV), and a single nucleus (Nu). The anchoring disk (AD) at the anterior end of the spore is the site of attachment of the polar tube. It should be noted that the polar tube is often called the polar filament when it is within the spore prior to germination. The anterior or straight region of the polar tube that connects to the anchoring disk is called the manubroid (M), and the posterior region of the tube coils around the sporoplasm. The number of coils and their arrangement (i.e., single row or multiple rows) are used in microsporidian taxonomic classification. The lamellar polaroplast (Pl) and vesicular polaroplast (VPl) surround the manubroid region of the polar tube. The insert depicts the five polar tube coils in this figure in a cross section, illustrating that the polar tube within the spore (i.e., polar filament) has several layers of different electron density by electron microscopy. (B) Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of Encephalitozoon intestinalis infecting a host cell (Vero E6) in tissue culture. The white arrow points to the extruded polar tube. (Both panels reprinted with permission from reference 40.)

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENERA AND SPECIES
sect2.para: Microsporidia are classically classified by their ultrastructural features, which include the number of coils of their polar tube; the size, shape, and morphology of their spores; the features of their developmental life cycle; and their host-parasite relationship (Fig. 2 and 3). Molecular phylogenetic data, such as 16S small subunit rRNA sequences, provide a complementary set of data for assigning microsporidia to specific genera as well as distinguishing morphologically similar microsporidia at the species level (69, 70). These molecular data demonstrate the polyphyletic nature of the current classification of microsporidia based on ultrastructural features. Overviews of the ultrastructural and structural characteristics, life cycle differences, and microsporidian taxa can be found in work by Tuzet et al. (71), Sprague (9), Larsson (72), Issi (73), Weiser (74), and Sprague et al. (75). Microsporidia are currently separated into three main groups: (i) the “primitive” microsporidia (Metchnikovellidae), which are hyperparasites of gregarines found in annelids and have a rudimentary polar filament and lack a polaroplast in their spores; (ii) the Burkeidae, Chytridopsidae, and Hesseidsae, which have a short polar filament and minimal development of a polaroplast and endospore; and (iii) the “higher” microsporidia, which possess a well-developed polar filament, a polaroplast, and a posterior vacuole. Differences among modern classifications of microsporidia focus on the characteristics used to divide the third group, the higher microsporidia, into subgroups. The microsporidia that infect humans (Table 1) are found in the higher microsporidia. The developmental characteristics of these species are illustrated in Fig. 3.

Anncaliia spp. have diplokaryotic nuclei, develop in direct contact with their host cell cytoplasm, and produce electron-dense extracellular secretions and vesiculotubular appendages. Anncaliia vesicularum (formerly Brachiola vesicularum) produces 2.5- by 2-μm diplokaryotic spores containing 7 to 10 anisofilar coils of the polar filament arranged in one to three rows, usually two (12). On the basis of diplokaryotic nuclei, disporoblastic sporogony, and the formation of vesiculotubular secretions, Brachiola (Nosema) connori and Brachiola (Nosema) algerae, which also cause human infections, were also reclassified as species of Anncaliia (13). Spores of Anncaliia connori measure 2.0 to 2.5 by 4.0 to 4.5 μm and contain polar tubes with 10 to 12 coils (76). Spores of Anncaliia algerae measure 3.7 to 5.4 by 2.3 to 3.9 μm and have 8 to 11 coils of the polar tube (77).

Encephalitozoon spp. develop intracellularly in parasitophorous vacuoles bounded by a membrane that is probably of host cell origin. Nuclei of all stages are unpaired. Meronts divide repeatedly by binary fission and lie close to the vacuolar membrane. Sporonts appear free in the center of the vacuole and divide into two or four sporoblasts, which mature into spores. The spores measure 1.0 to 1.5 by 2.0 to 3.0 μm, and the polar tube has four to eight isofilar coils.

Encephalitozoon cuniculi was identified and isolated from many animals before human infections were identified. Human and animal isolates of Encephalitozoon cuniculi are morphologically identical. Encephalitozoon hellem was identified in 1991 on the basis of different SDS-PAGE protein patterns than seen in Encephalitozoon cuniculi isolates (20). Encephalitozoon (Septata) intestinalis was described in 1993 as belonging to a new genus Septata on the basis of a pathogen-secreted fibrillar network that surrounds the developing organisms, giving the parasitophorous vacuoles a septate appearance (15); however, based on molecular phylogenetic data, it was reassigned to the genus Encephalitozoon. Based on differences in the sequence of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rRNA, four “groups” of Encephalitozoon cuniculi have been identified which differ in animal-host preferences and geographic distributions (78, 79).

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Developmental life cycle of the microsporidia. Spores germinate when they are exposed to specific environmental conditions, which vary depending on the species of microsporidia. Upon germination, the polar tube is extruded and interacts with the host cell membrane, allowing invasion. The sporoplasm transverses the polar tube, is introduced into the host cell cytoplasm, and begins to proliferate. The morphology of the organism during the proliferative phase (indicated by the region above the dotted line) is used in classification systems defining the various microsporidian genera. Relationships of the various microsporidia with their host cells during the proliferative phase are described in Table 2. The left side of the figure illustrates the uninucleate sporoplasm: the microsporidian genera that are defined during the development of spores—i.e., the sporogenic phase (indicated by the region below the dotted line)—are all uninucleate. On the right, the sporoplasm is diplokaryotic and all of the microsporidia genera defined during spore development have diplokaryotic developmental patterns. Regardless of whether they are uninucleate or diplokarytoic, there are three basic types of developmental forms. The first developmental pathway, as illustrated by Anncaliia spp., involves cell division by binary fission that immediately follows karyokinesis. The second type of pathway, as illustrated by some Nosema spp., involves multiple fission of elongated moniliform multinucleate cells. The third type of developmental pathway, as illustrated by Endoreticulatus spp., involves the division by plasmotomy of rounded plasmodial multinucleate cells. During the proliferative phase, cells can have one to several division cycles. Many microsporidia are either in direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm or closely abutted to the host endoplasmic reticulum; however, other microsporidia are found within a parasitophorous vacuole (e.g., Encephalitozoon spp. and probably Tetramicra spp.) or are separated from the host cell cytoplasm by a thick layer of their own secretions (e.g., Pleistophora spp.). In the sporogenic phase, this thick layer of microsporidian secretions becomes the sporophorous vesicle. During sporogony, several of the microsporidian genera, such as Enterocytozoon, Nosema, Anncaliia, Ichthyosporidium, and Tetramicra, maintain direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm. A sporophorous vesicle, illustrated by the circle around the developing sporogonial stage, is formed by the other microsporidian genera. During the developmental cycle of Thelohania and the Thelohania-like part of the Vairimorpha cycle, it should be noted that the diplokarya separate and continue their development as cells with isolated nuclei. (Reprinted with permission from reference 277.)

sect2.para: Endoreticulatus spp. have been identified as causing human infection in two patients on the basis of molecular phylogenetic findings; however, ultrastructural information is not available on these cases (29).

Enterocytozoon bieneusi develops in direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm. The proliferative and sporogonial forms are rounded, multinucleate plasmodia with unpaired nuclei, measuring up to 6 μm in diameter. The oval spores measure 0.7 to 1.0 by 1.1 to 1.6 μm. The polar tube, derived from electron-dense disks in sporonts, has five to seven isofilar coils that appear in two rows when seen in transverse section by transmission electron microscopy (14). Numerous genotypes have been identified, with differences in host specificity and zoonotic potential (80).

figure.title: FIGURE 3 Identifying developmental characteristics of the microsporidian genera described as etiologic in human infections. (A) Anncaliia. Members of this genus are diplokaryotic and disporoblastic; the life cycle is like that of Nosema, but meronts are bizarrely shaped and possess a surface coat with vesiculotubular structures (vt) embedded in it and extending from it. (B) Vittaforma. Members of this genus are diplokaryotic and polysporoblastic; all stages, including spores, are isolated in a close-fitting, ribosome-studded cisterna of host endoplasmic reticulum (er). (C) Pleistophora. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and polysporoblastic; meronts and sporonts are multinucleate stages called plasmodia; a thick surface coat is already present on meronts and sporonts (1); this coat separates from the sporogonial plasmodium to form a cyst-like vesicle, the sporophorous vesicle; the plasmodium divides within it to produce numerous spores (2). (D) Trachipleistophora. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and polysporoblastic. The meront surface coat has branched extensions (1); these are withdrawn when the coat separates to form the sporophorous vesicle around a uninucleate sporont; the sporont undergoes a series of binary fissions (2, 3) and finally encloses numerous spores (4). (E) Encephalitozoon. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and di- or tetrasporoblastic; all stages of the life cycle, developing from the sporoplasm, occur concurrently within a host cell vacuole (parasitophorous vacuole); merogonic stages are appressed against the vacuole wall; sporogonic stages are free; the vacuole is finally packed with spores, so that it superficially resembles a sporophorous vesicle. (F) Enterocytozoon. Members of this genus are monokaryotic and polysporoblastic; meronts (1) have irregular nuclei and lucent clefts; sporonts (2) are multinucleate with rounded nuclei and have highly characteristic electron-dense disks, which are polar tube precursors; all spore organelles are formed prematurely, so that constriction around the sets of organelles and a nucleus (3) gives rise directly to almost mature spores. The surface coat is deposited only during constriction. (Adapted with permission from reference 278.)

sect2.para: Nosema spp. develop in direct contact with host cell cytoplasm; nuclei are paired (diplokaryotic); divisions are by binary fission, and sporonts are disporoblastic. The majority of Nosema species that have been described in humans have been reclassified to other genera. Currently, Nosema ocularum is the only human infection that has been retained in this genus, and it is only known from a single case description (81). Spores measure 3 by 5 μm and have polar tubes with 9 to 12 coils.

Pleistophora spp., including Pleistophora ronneafiei, have unpaired nuclei, and all stages are multinucleate plasmodia, which divide into smaller multinucleate segments. Meronts have a thick, amorphous coat, which separates from the surface in sporogony to form a sporophorous vesicle. Sporogonic divisions give rise to a large and variable number of spores, packaged in the persistent sporophorous vesicle. The spores contain polar tubes with 9 to 12 coils and measure 2 to 2.8 by 3.3 to 4.0 μm (22).

Trachipleistophora hominis forms spores in sporophorous vesicles; these arise from repeated binary fissions and not from multinucleate plasmodia. The vesicles, which contain 2 to more than 32 spores, enlarge as the spore number increases. The nuclei are unpaired in all stages of development. The pear-shaped spores measure 2.4 by 4.0 μm and have about 11 anisofilar coils (82). Trachipleistophora anthropophthera is similar to Trachipleistophora hominis but appears to be dimorphic, as two different forms of sporophorous vesicles and spores have been observed (83).

Tubulinosema acridophagus was identified based on molecular phylogenetic data in two cases (27, 28) and has also been documented by electron microscopy (84). Ultrastructurally, all developing stages are in direct contact with the host cell cytoplasm. Spore size ranges from 1.4 to 2.4 μm in length; nuclei are diplokaryotic, and polar filaments are anisofilar and contain 11 coils arranged mostly in single rows, although in some spores double rows are present.

Vittaforma corneae was originally classified as Nosema corneum, but was transferred to a new genus on the basis of its ultrastructural features (11). Nuclei are diplokaryotic; sporogony is polysporoblastic; sporonts are ribbon-shaped, and all stages, including spores, are individually enveloped by a cisterna of host endoplasmic reticulum studded with ribosomes. The spores contain polar tubes with five to seven coils and measure 1.2 by 3.8 μm (85).

Microsporidium is a collective generic name for microsporidia that cannot be classified because available information is not sufficient. Microsporidium ceylonensis and Microsporidium africanum were each described in case reports of single cases of infection (86).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Infections in humans due to microsporidia occur globally and have been detected in molecular paleontology investigations of samples from Neanderthals (87). An epidemic of microsporidian infections, mainly Enterocytozoon bieneusi or Encephalitozoon intestinalis, was reported in humans due to the AIDS pandemic prior to the availability of combination antiretroviral therapy (cART). A recent meta-analysis in 2018 of 131 studies examining microsporidia, Cryptosporidium, and Cystoisospora infections in HIV-infected individuals, using a random effects model, found a pooled prevalence of 11.8% (CI: 10.1% to 13.4%) for human gastrointestinal microsporidiosis (88). A lower prevalence of infection was found in high-income countries and a higher prevalence in low-income countries, especially in sub-Saharan Africa (88). While it is clear from several studies that cART can hasten the resolution of microsporidiosis, the literature contains many reports that microsporidia can still be a problem despite cART, especially if the CD4 count remains low (89–92). Microsporidia are opportunistic pathogens, and depressed cell-mediated immunity (93, 94) is a major risk factor, with individuals with a CD4 T-lymphocyte count below 50 to 100 cells/mm3 having high susceptibility to infection (95). Other immune-suppressed patients are also at risk; i.e., cases have occurred in patients on chemotherapy, in organ transplant recipients, and in bone marrow graft recipients (96–106). There have been several cases of the transmission of microsporidiosis due to various transplanted organs (107, 108); for example, Encephalitozoon cuniculi infections were diagnosed in three patients with neurological symptoms following solid organ transplantation (kidney, liver, and heart/kidney) (108). Encephalitozoon cuniculi and Enterocytozoon bieneusi infections have been reported in transplant recipients who presented with fever of unknown origin (101, 102, 105, 107, 109).

In addition to immune-suppressed patients, microsporidiosis has also been reported in immune-competent hosts including travelers and residents of tropical countries (3.3 to 10%), children with and without diarrhea (1.7 to 17.4%), and the elderly (17.2%) (110–114). Latent infection associated with spore passage has also been reported in immune-competent humans (115). While self-limited diarrhea is the most common manifestation of microsporidiosis in immune-competent hosts, keratoconjunctivitis due to Vittaforma corneae has been reported in numerous immune-competent patients in Asia, including several outbreak clusters associated with soil exposure (8, 116, 117), and cases of conjunctivitis due to Vittaforma corneae have occurred in patients who have traveled to Asia (118). Anecdotally, sporadic cases have occurred in other countries in Europe and North America.

Microsporidia are pathogens of numerous invertebrates and vertebrates, infecting virtually every major animal group (2–8), and spores are shed into the environment, increasing the probability for human exposure. The exact sources of microsporidia infecting humans and their modes of transmission are uncertain, but ingestion of the environmentally highly resistant spores is probably the most important mode of transmission. Microsporidian spores are often found in surface water, and human pathogenic microsporidia have been found in municipal water supplies (119), hospital effluent (120), tertiary sewage effluent, and ground water (121, 122). Direct contact with water during bathing in hot spring spas was associated with keratoconjunctivitis due to microsporidia (123). The consumption of untreated water has been a risk factor for infection among travelers and residents; contact lens use is a strongly associated risk factor in microsporidian keratoconjunctivitis; and both young and advanced age have been identified as risk factors for infection (110, 124–127). Transmission by dust or aerosol has also been considered on the basis of respiratory or ocular infections (21, 128). Microsporidiosis in humans has occurred in the respiratory mucosa, prostate, and urogenital tract of patients, suggesting that respiratory and sexual transmission are possible routes of human transmission (129, 130). Encephalitozoon cuniculi has been demonstrated to be transmissible via rectal infection in rabbits (131). In humans, both oral-anal contact and anal penetration during sex have been identified as risk factors for gastrointestinal microsporidiosis (132–134). Foodborne outbreaks associated with microsporidia have been reported (135, 136). In a study conducted in agricultural markets in the Central Valley of Costa Rica, microsporidia were detected in cilantro, parsley, lettuce, blackberries, and strawberries (137), and microsporidian DNA has been detected in milk from dairy cows (138). While congenital transmission of microsporidia occurs in many mammals, it has not been seen in humans (139).

Direct zoonotic transmission of microsporidia is probable, as microsporidia species that infect humans also infect many other animals (4, 8). Direct evidence of zoonotic transmission is provided by a case report of a child who was infected with Encephalitozoon cuniculi after being exposed to an infected litter of puppies, and a 2-year-old child who was infected with Enterocytozoon bieneusi after being exposed to infected guinea pigs (140, 141). Molecular studies of the Encephalitozoon cuniculi rRNA ITS region have defined four strains causing natural infections in rabbits, rodents, tamarins, cats, dogs, and a variety of wild animals (79). HIV-infected patients have been identified with infections due to strain I (“rabbit strain”), II (“mouse strain”), and III (“dog strain”) (4, 78, 79, 142, 143), and strain IV (“human strain”) has been seen in a renal transplant recipient (18) as well as in cats and dogs (79). Encephalitozoon spp. have been detected in psittacines kept in aviaries, in a variety of wild birds including pigeons (144), in domestic animals in Mexico (145), and in gorillas in Uganda. Studies of urban pigeons suggested potential zoonotic transmission of Encephalitozoon intestinalis and Encephalitozoon hellem between birds and humans, and visiting urban parks was identified as a high-risk factor for microsporidiosis in children and the elderly (146). Enterocytozoon bieneusi, while originally described in humans, has been found in a wide variety of animals, including wildlife, livestock, and companion animals, and in several reports the onset of human infection has been associated with exposure to fowl, budgerigars, lovebirds, or livestock (4, 135, 143, 147, 148). Genetic analyses of Enterocytozoon bieneusi revealed two major groups, one comprising anthroponotic genotypes and the other containing multiple genotypes with zoonotic potential (149, 150). Tubulinosema and Anncaliia are pathogens of insects (62, 63). Nosema and Vittaforma infections in humans are thought to be due to the inoculation of environmental spores of insect pathogens into the cornea (4).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: While microsporidia are seen in patients with advanced HIV infection, they are not limited to this condition and have been reported in other immunocompromised and immune-competent hosts (5, 7, 8, 31, 61, 151–153). Microsporidia associated with human infection and related clinical manifestations are summarized in Table 1. There are limited data in humans on the immune response to microsporidiosis; however, from studies in mice it is clear that T cells are critically important in this infection (154–156). In addition to patients with AIDS, microsporidiosis has been described in solid-organ transplant recipients (105, 107, 108), allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients (157, 158), patients with hematologic malignancies receiving monoclonal antibody therapy (159), patients with rheumatic disease undergoing anti-tumor necrosis factor therapy (160), the elderly (110), and malnourished children (161). In immune-competent hosts, infections due to microsporidia have presented as self-limiting diarrhea (162), latent asymptomatic infections (115), central nervous system infection (2, 17, 19, 108, 151, 163–167), and various ocular infections including keratoconjunctivitis (116, 117, 123, 168–171), keratoconjunctivitis in contact lens wearers (127), and keratoconjunctivitis after corneal collagen cross-linking (a noninvasive technique to treat keratoconus) (172). The clinical manifestations of microsporidiosis are diverse, varying according to the mode of transmission, the causal species, and the underlying host immune status and response (61). Although most reported cases of microsporidiosis involve diarrhea, the gamut of diseases caused by these organisms includes myositis, kidney and urogenital infection, cholangitis, ascites, sinusitis, hepatitis, keratoconjunctivitis, and disseminated infection, as well as asymptomatic infection (8, 31, 61, 93, 173).

sect1.title: Enterocytozoon bieneusi
sect1.para: Enterocytozoon bieneusi infection was initially reported in a Haitian AIDS patient with diarrhea and wasting (14); subsequently, infection causing diarrhea was recognized in non-immune-compromised travelers (126) and in organ transplant recipients (158, 174–177). In immunocompetent adults and in children, Enterocytozoon bieneusi can cause self-limited watery diarrhea (lasting up to 2 to 3 weeks), particularly among persons who reside or have traveled in tropical countries (178); diarrhea in malnourished children in the tropics (161); and acute and chronic diarrhea in elderly individuals in resource-rich countries (110). It is the most commonly seen microsporidium in human infections, causing 90% of cases of chronic diarrhea in patients with AIDS (2, 153). Enterocytozoon bieneusi infects the enterocytes of the small intestine, leading to increased cell turnover and villous blunting; the epithelial cells of the pancreas; and the epithelial cells of the biliary tree, causing cholangiopathy. Clinical disease is associated with decreased brush border enzyme activities and malabsorption. There are also reports of this pathogen being seen in epithelial cells of the respiratory tract (179). Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography, computerized axial tomography, abdominal ultrasonography, or endoscopic ultrasonography often demonstrates irregularities of the bile duct wall, dilated biliary ducts, and gallbladder abnormalities such as distention, thickening, or the presence of sludge. Spores are found within the apical portion of the enterocyte cytoplasm rather than the basilar cytoplasm, and infection is not seen in cells in the lamina propria (2, 61, 180–182).

sect1.title: Encephalitozoon spp.
sect1.para: Encephalitozoon species including E. intestinalis, E. hellem, and E. cuniculi are widely distributed in mammals and have been identified in both immune-competent and immune-compromised humans (5, 182). Consistent with their ability to disseminate widely in their hosts and to infect numerous organs, these pathogens can infect a wide variety of host cells including epithelial cells, endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and macrophages (2, 8, 31, 183). Infection with Encephalitozoon spp. was first described in two children with a seizure disorder (163, 164), and since then other cases of encephalitis have been identified (2, 17, 19, 108, 151, 163–167). Encephalitozoonidae have been described as etiologic in cases of sinusitis, bronchiolitis, nephritis, keratitis, peritonitis, hepatitis, fulminant hepatic failure, gastroenteritis, cerebritis, cystitis, urethritis, prostatitis, nodular skin lesions, and disseminated infection (2, 8, 17, 20, 31, 142, 165, 184–190). Clinical manifestations may vary substantially, ranging from an asymptomatic carrier state to organ failure. Encephalitozoon cuniculi endocarditis has been reported in a non-immunocompromised patient with a dual-chamber pacemaker (191). Encephalitozoon cuniculi has been found in the periprosthetic tissue of several patients in Poland who presented with hip implant loosening requiring hip replacement, despite an absence of symptoms associated with infection (192). Encephalitozoon intestinalis infects primarily enterocytes, but the organism is also found in intestinal lamina propria, and dissemination to the kidneys, airways, and biliary tract appears to occur via infected macrophages (15). Chronic diarrhea and disseminated disease due to Encephalitozoon intestinalis have been diagnosed mainly in immune-deficient patients, and ~10% of cases of diarrhea and wasting in immune-deficient patients with AIDS are caused by Encephalitozoon intestinalis (193). A case of nodular cutaneous Encephalitozoon intestinalis infection was observed in a patient with AIDS (188). Furthermore, Encephalitozoon intestinalis has been detected in stool specimens from healthy children and adults, with or without diarrhea, living in Mexico (194), and among travelers with diarrhea returning from tropical countries (195).

sect1.title: Other Microsporidia
sect1.para: Several other microsporidia have been isolated from both immune-competent and immune-deficient persons (151, 152) (Table 1). These presentations have included keratoconjunctivitis, keratitis, corneal ulcers (171), and reactive arthritis (196). Vittaforma corneae was first described as Nosema corneum in a stromal biopsy from a patient without HIV, and it is now recognized to be responsible for keratoconjunctivitis in healthy persons (with over 300 cases being reported associated with water or soil exposure) and HIV-infected patients (11, 85, 197–201). Disseminated infections and myositis have been seen due to infection with Pleistophora spp. (202), Pleistophora ronneafiei (22), Trachipleistophora hominis (25), Anncaliia vesicularum (Brachiola vesicularum) (12), Anncaliia algerae (Nosema/Brachiola algerae) (203, 204), and Tubulinosema acridophagus (27, 28). Anncaliia algerae has also been isolated from erythematous skin nodules from a child with acute lymphocytic leukemia (205). Disseminated infection due to Anncaliia connori (Nosema connori) was found at autopsy in a 4-month-old athymic male infant (76). Myositis due to Endoreticulatus spp. was diagnosed in an otherwise healthy man in Thailand (29). Disseminated Trachipleistophora anthropophthera involving cerebral, cardiac, renal, pancreatic, thyroid, hepatic, splenic, lymphoid, and bone marrow tissues was identified at autopsy in patients with AIDS who presented with seizures (26).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: As a consequence of the recognition of microsporidia as opportunistic pathogens, the diagnostic procedures for detection of these organisms have dramatically improved (206). With these improved techniques there has been increasing recognition of microsporidia infection in immune-competent humans (114, 153, 169, 207). Enteric microsporidia can be detected in fresh or fixed (10% formalin or in sodium acetate-acetic acid-formalin) stool specimens, duodenal aspirates, or biopsy samples. Furthermore, spores from disseminated microsporidian infection are often detectable in fresh or fixed (usually with formalin) urine sediments and other body fluids such as sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, nasal secretions, cerebrospinal fluid, and conjunctival smears, as well as in corneal scrapings or tissue biopsy material. Identification of microsporidia at the species level can be done by molecular techniques (e.g., a species-specific PCR assay) or by ultrastructural examination (e.g., electron microscopy of tissue fixed using glutaraldehyde). Isolation of microsporidia using tissue culture has not been useful for routine clinical diagnosis; however, these organisms have been cultured in a variety of commonly used cell lines, and the collection of clinical samples (without fixative) can be extremely important for the identification and characterization of novel microsporidia. It should be appreciated that microsporidian spores are environmentally resistant and can remain infectious for several years if protected from desiccation (208).

sect2.title: DETECTION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: The most robust technique for the diagnosis of infection is the detection of spores of microsporidia in clinical material by light microscopy. This is accomplished by the use of stains that produce differential contrast between the spores of microsporidia and the cells and debris in clinical samples (Fig. 4 and 5). Chromotrope 2R stains and chemofluorescent stains have markedly improved the detection of microsporidia in body fluids and stool samples (180).

Microsporidia pathogenic to humans have spores that range in size from 1 to 4 μm. Examination of stool specimens by light microscopy is the standard technique for diagnosing gastrointestinal microsporidiosis. The differences in the sizes ofEnterocytozoon bieneusi spores (1 to 1.5 μm) and Encephalitozoonidae spores (2 to 3 μm) often permit a tentative identification of the genus from light-microscopic examination of stool specimens. Since renal involvement, with shedding of spores in the urine, is common in microsporidia that disseminate, urine specimens should be obtained whenever the diagnosis of microsporidiosis is being considered. In contrast to stool, it is easier to identify microsporidial spores in body fluids because of the absence of bacteria and debris that could be confused with microsporidial spores. This has therapeutic implications, as microsporidia that disseminate (e.g., Encephalitozoonidae) are susceptible to albendazole, whereas those that do not disseminate (e.g., Enterocytozoon bieneusi) are resistant. Determination of the definitive characterization of the species of microsporidia causing an infection can be accomplished by electron microscopy or genetic analysis (5, 8, 208).

sect2.title: Preparation of Smears, Staining, and Microscopic Examination
sect2.para: Smears are usually prepared from 10 to 20 μl of unconcentrated stool which is very thinly spread onto slides, as coprological procedures used to concentrate ova and parasites (i.e., helminth eggs and protozoa) fail to concentrate microsporidia spores. It should be noted, however, that formalin-ethyl acetate concentration and other different flotation methods can remove significant amounts of fecal debris, and smears prepared from such concentrates can be easier to read by light microscopy, though such smears are less sensitive (209). Chromotrope-based stains (209) and chemofluorescent optical brightening agents (210, 211), including calcofluor white and other chemofluorescent stains, are the most commonly used stains for detecting microsporidia. The proteinaceous exospore and the chitinous endospore of microsporidia make it possible to stain spores with different methods such as Giemsa, Gram, or trichrome stains and fluorescent dyes (i.e., Uvitex 2B and calcofluor white). It is important, no matter which staining technique is utilized, to use positive-control material when performing stains for microsporidia. Demonstration of microsporidia by light microscopy requires the use of stains that produce differential contrast between the spores of microsporidia and the cells and debris in clinical samples. As spores are 1 to 4 μm in size, magnification using a 60× to 100× objective is required for their visualization.

sect2.title: Chromotrope-Based Staining Procedures
sect2.para: The Chromotrope 2R staining technique described by Weber et al. is based on a modification of routine trichrome staining using a 10-fold higher concentration of Chromotrope 2R and a longer staining time (209). Modifications of this staining method, which are preferred by some laboratories, have been described by Ryan and coworkers (212) (using aniline blue in place of fast green) and by Kokoskin and colleagues (213) (using a higher temperature). Spores stained by Chromotrope 2R, against a green (Weber stain) or blue (Ryan stain) background, will appear as ovoid, light pink structures that are usually 1 to 3 μm in size, and these spores will often display a beltlike stripe girding them diagonally and equatorially (Fig. 4 and 5B and C) (209). The spore wall stains bright pinkish red and some spores appear transparent. Other fecal elements, such as Cyclospora, Cryptosporidia, yeast, and some bacteria, may also stain reddish, but they can be distinguished from microsporidial spores by their size, shape, and staining pattern. Several additional modifications of the original chromotrope-staining solution have been developed, such as the hot Gram-chromotrope technique, which stains microsporidian spores dark violet in a much shorter period of time (214), and an acid-fast trichrome stain (215), which permits visualization of acid-fast cryptosporidial oocysts and microsporidial spores on the same slide.

sect2.title: Chemofluorescent Agents
sect2.para: Fluorescent stains that bind to chitin in the spore wall of microsporidia, such as Calcofluor White M2R, Uvitex 2B, Fungi-Fluor, Fungiqual A, Cellufluor, and other chemofluorescent optical brighteners, are also useful for visualizing microsporidian spores in various clinical samples (Fig. 5D) (208). These stains are easy and quick, but they also stain fungi and other fecal elements (211). The chitinous spore wall of a microsporidian spore fluoresces brightly, facilitating detection. However, chemofluorescent optical brighteners are not specific, and yeast, which can be present in fecal material, and other fecal elements may also be brightened. Microsporidia can be distinguished from yeast by their size and lack of budding.

Epidemiological comparisons of the chromotrope-staining technique with methods that use chemofluorescent optical brighteners indicate that both of these test methods are robust for routine use and both methods have excellent sensitivity and specificity (100% for Chromotrope 2R and 90 to 100% for chemofluorescent stains) (211, 216–218). The limit of detecting microsporidia by either of these techniques appears to be 50,000 organisms/ml. Some laboratories use both staining techniques because the chromotrope stains result in a highly specific visualization of spores, whereas the chemofluorescent agents may be more sensitive but may produce false-positive results (218). While spores from microsporidia can be found in food and insects and can produce a false-positive result, this has not been a significant problem in clinical practice. Neither staining method allows definitive species-specific identification of microsporidia.

sect2.title: Immunofluorescent-Antibody Tests
sect2.para: Monoclonal antibodies to Encephalitozoonidae (Encephalitozoon hellem [219], Encephalitozoon intestinalis [220, 221], and Enterocytozoon bieneusi [222–224]) have been developed and evaluated for diagnostic purposes to use immunofluorescence or other immunostaining techniques to detect microsporidia in tissue sections, stool, and other body fluids. A commercial indirect fluorescent-antibody assay has become available (Bordier Affinity Products, Switzerland; CE marked but not FDA approved). For Enterocytozoon bieneusi, compared to PCR, the sensitivity was 95.2% and specificity was 100% for this indirect fluorescent-antibody assay; compared to a modified trichrome stain, sensitivity was 100% and specificity was 99.4% (225).

sect1.title: Cytological Diagnosis
sect1.para: Spores from microsporidia can be detected by examination of the sediment obtained by centrifugation of body fluids for 10 min at 500 ×g. Detection by this method has been reported in duodenal aspirates, bile, biliary aspirates, urine (Fig. 5C), bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (Fig. 5B), and cerebrospinal fluid and in smears of conjunctival swabs, sputum, and nasal discharge. Examination of smears of centrifuged duodenal aspirates obtained during endoscopy has been shown to be a highly sensitive technique for the diagnosis of intestinal microsporidiosis. As microsporidia can infect multiple organs, the detection of microsporidia in virtually any tissue or body fluid should prompt a thorough search of other sites. In particular, urine specimens should be examined in cases of intestinal microsporidiosis, as the presence of microsporidia in urine can help differentiate Encephalitozoonidae infections from infection due to E. bieneusi (2, 208).

sect1.title: Examination of Biopsy Specimens and Corneal Scrapings
sect1.para: Examination of duodenal and terminal ileal tissue has been useful for the diagnosis of intestinal microsporidiosis; however, as these pathogens are rarely found in the colon, examination of colonic biopsy has not been useful clinically for the diagnosis of intestinal microsporidiosis. Disseminated infection due to microsporidia has been reported in almost every organ system (2, 61, 151). The identification of microsporidia in tissue stained with routine techniques such as hematoxylin and eosin staining is difficult and requires a highly experienced pathologist. Ultrathin plastic sections stained with methylene blue-azure II-basic fuchsin or with toluidine blue may facilitate detection (2, 8, 208). Selective microsporidian stains improve the rate of detection of microsporidia in tissue. Tissue Gram stains (Brown-Brenn or Brown-Hopps) have proven useful for the rapid and reliable identification of HIV-associated microsporidia in routine paraffin-embedded tissue sections (Fig. 5A) and corneal scrapings (2, 8, 208). With this stain, spores from microsporidia are Gram variable and are easily identified because of the contrasting dark blue or reddish staining against a faint brown-yellow background. Microsporidia can also be identified in tissue using silver stains (Warthin-Starry stain) (226), chromotrope-based staining techniques, chemofluorescent agents, or a Luna stain (227).

sect1.title: Molecular Techniques
sect1.para: The successful sequencing of various microsporidia genomes has led to the application of molecular-based techniques for the diagnosis of microsporidia infections in humans (180; see Weiss and Vossbrinck [69] and Ghosh and Weiss [228] for reviews of molecular diagnostic tests for microsporidiosis). Universal panmicrosporidian and genus- or species-specific PCR primer pairs that target the 16S small subunit rRNA gene have been well characterized for diagnosis and species identification (3, 8, 228–230). Using PCR, Enterocytozoon bieneusi and the Encephalitozoonidae have been identified in fresh stool specimens, formalin-fixed stool specimens, intestinal tissue obtained by endoscopic biopsy, urine specimens, and other body fluids. Nucleic acids are isolated from clinical specimens by mechanical disruption of the microsporidia spores, combined with using lyticase and/or chitinase to increase the efficiency of DNA extraction (180, 231). PCR-based methods have been shown to be able to detect 100 to 1,000 spores/ml in clinical samples (232, 233). A real-time PCR method was developed for quantitation of Enterocytozoon bieneusi DNA (119) and Encephalitozoon intestinalis DNA (234) in stool specimens. An assay based on the loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) technique has been developed for Enterocytozoon bieneusi (235), as well as an in situ hybridization assay for identifying Enterocytozoon bieneusi in tissue sections (236).

sect2.title: ISOLATION OF MICROSPORIDIA
sect2.para: The isolation of microsporidia is not used for routine diagnostic purposes, but is an important research tool and should be attempted for all atypical or novel microsporidia seen in clinical samples. Microsporidia cannot be grown axenically.Encephalitozoon spp., Trachipleistophora hominis, Vittaforma corneae, and Ancaliia algerae have all been grown in various host cells including RK-13 (rabbit kidney), MDCK (Madin-Darby canine kidney), MRC-5 (human embryonic lung fibroblast), and other cells (86, 237, 238). More than 13 isolates of Encephalitozoon cuniculi, 30 isolates of Encephalitozon hellem, and 30 isolates of Encephalitozon intestinalis have been reported to be successfully cultured in vitro. These microsporidia parasites were isolated from various clinical samples including corneal scrapings, conjunctival biopsies, urine, sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, nasal mucosal biopsies, duodenal biopsies, and stool. A system for continuous in vitro culture of Enterocytozoon bieneusi has not been established (193, 239); however, short-term in vitro culture, with limited spore production, has been reported (239, 240).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: The identification of microsporidia and their taxonomy has traditionally been reliant on their ultrastructure and developmental life cycle as determined by electron microscopy, although molecular methods are now being used to help classify these organisms; e.g., the Encephalitozoonidae share most of their morphologic features, and genetic analyses are important for their identification and can also reveal subtype-specific variation (20, 78). Electron microscopy is the “gold standard” for diagnostic confirmation and species identification of microsporidia; however, it is not routinely used for diagnosis as it is less sensitive than light microscopy or molecular diagnostic tests (208). While mature spores seen in body fluids or stool samples can provide important ultrastructural data for species identification, definitive identification requires examination of the developmental life cycle seen in tissue samples (8, 61, 180, 241) (Fig. 6). Such ultrastructural studies are particularly important for the classification of new or novel microsporidia seen in tissue and should be accompanied by phylogenetic analyses of 16S small subunit ribosomal gene sequences derived from PCR using panmicrosporidian primers (8, 61, 85, 142, 242).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Serologic assays such as carbon immunoassay, indirect immunofluorescence test, enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, and immunoblot assays have been used to demonstrate microsporidian-specific antibodies in several species of animals. The utility of such tests in humans has not been demonstrated, as seroconversion has not been demonstrated to be useful for the diagnosis of active infection. The seroprevalence rate reported in human studies has been variable depending on the population studied, but rates as high as 42% have been seen (112, 132, 243–245). This suggests that asymptomatic infection is probably common with various microsporidia. Results of these serologic studies with humans, however, were not supported by the simultaneous detection of organisms in individuals with antibody responses. The use of recombinant polar tube protein antigens from Encephalitozoon cuniculi has been reported to provide improved specificity for such serological assays (246).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY
sect2.para: Microsporidiosis is often seen in immune-compromised hosts, especially in patients with advanced AIDS and CD4+ cell counts lower than 50/μl. Improved immune function can result in a clinical response in patients with gastrointestinal microsporidiosis, leading to elimination of the organism and normalization of the intestinal architecture (247–252). Based on these observations, the institution of effective cART is important as part of the primary treatment of microsporidiosis in the setting of AIDS.

sect2.para: Based on studiesin vitro and in vivo in animal models, as well as clinical data on microsporidiosis in humans, albendazole (which inhibits β-tubulin) and fumagillin (which inhibits methionine aminopeptidase type 2) have the most consistent activity against the microsporidia that cause human infections (151, 181, 253–260). Albendazole has been found to cause growth deformities of Encephalitozoon and Vittaforma and to reduce or eradicate these organisms in cell cultures; however, albendazole does not destroy mature microsporidial spores, and thus treatment may result in latent infection (261). Fumagillin, its analog TNP-470, nikkomycin Z, and fluoroquinolones have been shown in vitro to inhibit completely or partially the replication or spore germination of Encephalitozoon and Vittaforma (261, 262). Albendazole (2 to 4 weeks, 400 mg twice daily) can result in clinical cure of HIV-associated Encephalitozoonidae infection in parallel with the cessation of spore excretion (129, 257–260). Successful treatment of a case of disseminated Trachipleistophora acridophagus infection has been reported (84). Albendazole has been effective in patients with microsporidiosis due to Trachipleistophora hominis and in patients with infections due to Anncaliia spp. (12, 25, 203, 263). Albendazole is not effective against Enterocytozoon infection and does not reduce pathogen load, although previous observations had suggested that clinical improvement may occur in some patients. The sequences of both the Enterocytozoon (264) and Vittaforma β-tubulins contain amino acid residues associated with albendazole resistance, consistent with the observation that albendazole is less effective for the treatment of Enterocytozoon bieneusi infection (265). Fumagillin and its semisynthetic analogues (due to inhibition of microsporidian methionine aminopeptidase type 2) have both in vitro and in vivo activity against the Encephalitozoonidae and Vittaforma corneae. For the treatment of Enterocytozoon bieneusi gastrointestinal infections in patients with AIDS and in patients with various organ transplants, fumagillin (20 mg three times a day) has been effective (158, 253, 254, 260, 266–270). The main adverse event seen with fumagillin therapy has been reversible thrombocytopenia (253, 271).

Keratoconjunctivitis due to microsporidia (Encephalitozoonidae andVittaforma corneae) can be a self-limiting disease (116), may be cleared by repeated corneal swabbing or debridement (272–274), and may respond to systemic albendazole treatment (275) or to topical voriconazole application (276). Topical fumagillin has been used to treat ocular microsporidiosis due to Encephalitozoonidae in immune-compromised hosts (151, 181, 253–256).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: In immune-competent hosts, microsporidia can cause self-limited diarrhea or keratoconjunctivitis. Microsporidia are, however, predominantly opportunistic pathogens that cause disease in immune-deficient HIV-infected patients (with CD4 cell counts below 200/μl) and other immune-compromised patients, such as patients who have had an organ transplant. Stool examination or examination of other specimens is, therefore, indicated for these patient groups in particular, and microsporidia should be considered etiologic agents when detected in clinical specimens from such patients. Microsporidia have been reported to cause infection in almost every organ system, and examination for these pathogens should be considered in cases where other pathogens have been excluded.

Routine diagnosis of microsporidiosis is based upon microscopic detection of the spores of these pathogens in various clinical samples. While light-microscopic examination is sensitive and specific (especially in immune-compromised hosts), it does not allow identification of microsporidia to the genus and species level. Identification of species can be achieved by electron microscopy, which is relatively insensitive for the detection of microsporidia because only small samples are examined and sampling errors may occur, or by PCR assays and sequence analyses. Immune-competent hosts with microsporidiosis can excrete lower numbers of spores in feces or urine; therefore, light-microscopic detection procedures may not be as sensitive in this group, and molecular tests (PCR) should be considered in cases where the diagnosis is strongly suspected but the light microscopy is negative.
